article:
The 'Achievement Improvement Monitor (AIM)' program was a testing scheme used to
monitor the development of literacy and numeracy skills of school students in
Victoria, Australia. It ran for the first time in 2003.

The program was administered by the Victorian Curriculum and Assessment
Authority (VCAA). Reading, writing, spelling and numeracy tests, based on the
Victorian Essential Learning Standards (VELS), were undertaken by all Victorian
students in Years 3, 5, 7 and 9. The results were used as feedback and guidance
to students, parents and teachers, and were not used to grade students.

Schools and parents were advised of each studentâs results against VELS. At each
test point, teachers could identify students who would benefit from enrichment
activities or who may require further development in specific aspects of the
curriculum.

In 2008, the Australia-wide NAPLAN tests replaced the AIM program.
